Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned about the fundamentals of physics and useful approaches for problem solving.
How to most effectively avoid crying due to P Set pain.
Mechanics, some stuff pertaining to interstellar space, etc. What you'd expect from an intro physics class.
University physics skills
Learned a lot of introductory calculus-based physics. It seemed like we roughly covered what most AP Physics C.
In-depth intro to mechanics
Kinematics, Newton's Laws, Energy Conservation Theorem, Rotational Kinematics, Universal Gravitation, Simple Harmonic Oscillators, Waves.
I got such a great foundational understanding of mechanics.
I learned how to work through complicated problems, how to analyze things in the physical world, and also about the mathematical laws that describe things in the world around us.
I learned about how to deal with physical concepts in the realm of mechanics.
I learned the fundamentals of Newtonian physics mechanics, from kinematics, forces, energy, work, gravity, simple harmonic motion, rotational motion, and waves.
An understanding of  linear motion, momentum, Torque, gravitational motion
I learned quite a lot of physics.
I think I gain an appreciation of Taylor series and a better grasp on the application of calculus in physics
I learned physics. Like a lot of it.
I gained a very fundamental and comprehensive understanding of mechanics through this class. It was very insightful.
Perseverance.
I learned many essential physics concepts, such as kinematics, forces, rotational motion, etc. I can apply calculus to these concepts as well.
I learned the basics of mechanics.
Very good introductory physics class.
By the end of this course, I felt like I've learned nothing. What is physics? I don't know. Only take this course if you absolutely need to fulfill a requirement.
I truly learned how to solve a problem!
I learned how to do physics with calculus and improved my problem solving skills a lot.
I gained a deeper insight into physics, and developed skills in problem solving.
This course covered high school physics in the first two weeks, and immediately broadened my horizons regarding classical mechanics. It was a smooth introduction to calculus based physics.

Learned mechanics and with calculus. didn't take Physics C in high school so can't compare it to that, but would say I learned a good amount and by studying for exams and doing the problem sets (which were long and arduous).

While many of us had seen some of these concepts in high school before, this course pushed us to think critically and conceptually apply notions relating to motion, momentum, energy, forces, kinematics, and waves. I learned to solve problems more creatively using different approaches, and thought more deeply about these concepts beyond superficially plugging in equations.
this class taught me how to use math to derive the equations of motion from basic pronciples. it was a great class.
I learned a lot of physics and how to apply calculus to physics.

I learned about kinematics, forces, work/energy, momentum, relative motion, universal gravity, simple harmonic motion, and waves. I learned how to apply a basic understand acquired in class to very difficult problems on psets and exams.
How to solve many physics problems about kinematics, rotation, orbits, and energy.
Basic understanding of classic mechanical physics and lots of problem solving techniques.

I strengthened my understanding of physics, a subject that has traditionally given me trouble. I also learned how to more effectively approach solving problems. Furthermore, I learned a bit about how calculus is used in physics, though I'll probably learn more about that next semester.
I learned so much about mechanical physics, from kinematics (like projectiles), to forces, to spring and harmonic motion, to gravity and gravitational attraction, to momentum...and more!
I learned how to think in such a way to approach and solve physics problems.
Good understanding of kinematics and developed problem-solving skills generally because p-sets required the use of multiple concepts from class

Basic knowledge on University Physics
Ability to test under pressure 
Problem solving skills
I learned that its okay to struggle on classes and where to look for help with this class.
Mechanics
I learned about mechanics, ranging from projectile motion to simple harmonic motion.

I found this to be an incredibly interesting course. I learned the fundamentals of physics, along with time management and problem-solving skills. Each question required in depth thinking and use all of the skills and concepts we've learned.
I learned the general concepts in physics.
How to solve physics problems.
I was able to refine the physics that I knew and better grasp the concepts.
Kinematics, Motion, Waves, Springs, Oscillators, Mechanics. A very in-depth introduction to physics.
I acquired better problem solving capacities, and increased my capacity for analytical thought.
I gained problem solving skills and increased understanding of several basic physics topics.
I have taken algebra-based physics while in high school, so through this course I was able to better develop my knowledge of fundamental physics topics, while incorporating calculus.
Overall, through taking this course I learned about various topics in Physics.
Learn simple concepts in a very complex way.
Ability to understand the world through scientific lenses.
More in depth review of high school topics
You go over the basics of mechanics. Its nice because each topic is covered meticulously such that most students will feel confidently in what has been learned.
Mechanical Physics
I developed the ability to work at a steady pace in a rigorous course
Learned Physics fundamentals, mainly mechanics.
I learned a great deal about mechanics and the way of the world from this class. This class did a good job of explaining much of how things operate and move.

This physics course had both breadth and depth, and as someone who doesn't come from a physics background, it was intense. But the topics would cover most topics in like a good AP Physics class but the class does move quickly and does obviously go much more in depth than an AP Physics class. You learn how to collaborate on p-sets (because you have to), and get the help that you need because I personally needed it to get through this class.

I took basic physics in high school but this course provided a great background and basis understanding of the topic. I also learned to develop strong organizational skills and especially time management strategies to account for the "outside of class" time spent in study hall and office hours.
I learned a lot of math skills and skills in applying lessons I learned in lecture to various situations.
Learning the fundmentals of physics
All of first year physics from kinematics to harmonic motion.
I learned physics (kinematics, energy, momentum, etc)
This course helps you to develop the fundamental skills for analyzing problems in physics. It also provides an understanding of energy, kinematics, and rotational dynamics.
I learned that if you are lacking in mathematical background you may come away with essentially no physics knowledge from this course.
Deep understanding of introductory physics concepts in mechanics
Kinematics, energy, forces, center of mass, circular motion. Introductory physics.
This course prepared me in basics of physics knowledge I will need during my time at Yale.
A lot of physics I didn't understand before!

This course taught a lot of content, and should be a 3 day a week class instead of two days. Lectures were often very long and  laborious, and I think students would absorb more information if it was more spaced out. Also, the office hours are completely overcrowded and loud. There are not even enough chairs and tables for students, so many sit on the ground. It is an extremely stressful environment to work on problem sets that are already so intense. It is amazing that this class has so many office hours, but they need to be in a bigger space.

Steinacker is great and the lectures and lecture notes are very helpful. The problem sets take up my whole week and while I understand the point of having the problems assigned, you just come to resent the class when it gets in the way of your life.

The professor was really great and I liked the wide variety of options for getting help on homework, etc. I felt that we had an extremely knowledgeable professor that really boosted what we were able to get out of the course. Another strength is that Prof. Steinacker Some weaknesses were that Prof. Steinacker went WAY too fast in lecture. Sometimes I would lean over to ask a friend a question about the material and when I would look back up I'd be even more confused about everything because she would have covered several more things. Another thing - those problem sets. I was in study hall Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, and sometimes Thursday trying to get those done. If you want to improve the course, 1) have less time consuming psets and 2) maybe go a little slower in lecture.
Professor very enthusiastic, sometimes felt lost on p-sets. More problem tips rather than theoretical stuff.

Some of the problems sets were incredibly difficult and Adrian (although a wonderful person) was sometimes disorganized and her wording of the problems was not the best. The class also moved really fast through some complex topics and then went too slowly during easier topics. It would also have been nice for homework solutions to be posted shortly after the due date.
There is ample help available via peer tutors, office hours, study hall. P-sets force you to think deeper about material learned in class. Hard to pinpoint any weaknesses.
The course is very well designed, but it does assume that students have a strong calculus background.

Strengths:  You really learn so much, and with psets being such a large part of your grade, the focus is much more on actually working through problems and figuring things out than on cramming for tests.  Also, Steinacker is an amazing professor who genuinely cares about everyone's learning.
I can't think of how it could be improved.

This course does a great job of teaching you about physics. Professor Steinacker is a decent lecturer and her demonstrations are always fun to watch. And although the PSETs are difficult, there is a lot of help available, from office hours to study halls to peer tutors. Once you get past the initial barrier of difficult homework, the class is manageable.

Strengths: One the more unique aspects of this course compared to others is that most of the learning is done in the completion of the assigned problem sets, and it seems Professor Steinacker wants you think so as well, as demonstrated by the numerous opportunities given to students for help with PS completion (M-Th office hours, Su-Th study hall hours). The lectures themselves were helpful in providing an introduction to the concepts that would be solidified upon completion of the problem sets. The midterms and final were challenging for sure, but not impossible--Steinacker gives enough resources and direction for you to do well, provided you put in the time. In fact, that statement is true in regards to the course as a whole--very challenging, but conquerable with enough time and energy invested. My suggestion is to find a friend or friends you can work with, and develop a strategy for tackling the problem sets together--my friend and I figured out a method that would allow us to spend about 7 hours overall on each problem set (1 hr/problem average). Lastly, Prof. Steinacker is a great professor with a very unique personality. You'll be fascinated by her rugged sense of individualism, her confidence, and her unique humor. 
Weaknesses: It's difficult to make a subject like physics interesting, and Steinacker already does such a great job of doing so. I wonder if there are supplemental online resources that could be provided for students to understand concepts a little better (e.g. simulations, online activities that are not mandatory but perhaps available on Canvas).

The course content overall is quite good. In some cases I feel that it is made a little bit more complicated but this also makes it more interesting.

The course workload is huge and Psets will take sometimes 12+ hours to complete.

I think increasing the number of pset problems that were a simple demonstration of concept would be swell. Too often problems were convoluted. I feel as though the purpose of the psets were to use problem solving as a teaching technique, which is GREAT, but also simpler problems that lead up to more involved applications of equations and concepts would teach the material A LOT BETTER, and allow for self-directed learning as problems scaled up in difficulty, instead of necessitating the use of outside help at every turn because the question of how to set up this problem was so unapproachable. 

Otherwise, I support the use of hard psets. Physics is like the ultimate problem-solving subject, so I support the rigor of the intro class. But taking out a few hard problems and replacing them with slight easier "show of concept" ones would be helpful.

The class is very well taught and Professor Steinacker is very thorough in her examples. She also posts class notes for every single class and the solutions for every problem set.

The problem sets are often very time-consuming, and sometimes needlessly tedious and complicated.
Professor Steinacker is a gem - she is very interested in students, humorous.

The level of help you get in this class is amazing. There are so many TA office hours, peer tutors and Professor Steinecker is amazing. 

The P-sets are really challenging and they force you to think outside the box to find solutions. I sometimes thought that the questions on the p-set were so many that they overclouded the goal of the p-set which was to get an in-depth understanding of the subjects.
The psets are really long and time consuming, but they prepare you well for the exams
It's pretty hard not going to lie. But she is a really sweet professor so you want to do well.

The biggest weakness of the course was the grading of the problem sets. Before the final exam, the grading was three weeks behind. When the grading is so far behind, you miss the opportunity to fix any sort of conceptual mistakes you made in the class. I think problem set class can be awesome, but the grading needs to be prompt. I also think that midterms should count for more, it's a little weird that they're just 15% of the grade.

Strengths: Grueling PSETs that make you actually learn the material very in-depth. Lectures are very helpful and essential. I felt like my time was well spent in lecture (even though sometimes there is a lot of information to unpack).

Weaknesses: None that I can think of. This class was amazing.
It was very well designed

The strengths are that you can't help but learn a LOT about physics by the end of the semester. I enjoyed the lectures and the demonstrations.

The main issue with this class is the workload. I am willing to work very hard for a class, but for physics I spent several hours every single day working just to finish each problem set. Every evening I went to the study hall to work for hours. The problem is that this course took away from all the other interesting courses I was taking (including ones for my MAJOR), because I was forced to spend every spare moment on physics. I can't tell if that was worth it for the skills I learned. 

It could also be more accommodating to students without a background in physics, because we were thrown in with people who've taken years of AP physics and expected to perform the same.

This course was taught very well, but the PSETs were insane. The psets helped with learning but they took way too long. It took so long to finish the psets that I didn't have the time to study material beyond that.
Some of the lectures were very fast but class notes were provided which really helped fill the gaps in knowledge.
Professor Steinacker is a good lecturer to some, but I don't understand what is going on most of the time. That's why I don't go to class.
The problem sets are daunting. Making them a problem or two shorter would have substantially increased my learning because I would have been able to take my time and process each problem better.
Great professor - very caring and always willing to post helpful materials on Canvas after lecture. It's just an intro class, not much to change.

The course really succeeds in making you understand physical principles by working out the relationships and formulas that describe these phenomena yourself in the problems sets. The fact that you also have to apply these principles to entirely new situations with different stipulations also helps you understand these concepts more clearly.

Strengths: Steinecker, difficult weekly psets that prepare you for exams, exam revisions
Weaknesses: the course is hard, but you probably knew that if you are thinking about taking this
I wish there were discussion sections like in General Chemistry I, because its hard to get a TF's attention in study hall or Adriane's in office hours since there are so many students seeking help

The problem sets are pretty time consuming and intense and sometimes they were so difficult that I felt like I wasn't actually learning the material. Lectures were interesting but I felt that sometimes they moved too quickly or it was assumed that we had already learned the material.
Overall, I thought the course was great and didn't really have any weaknesses. The amount of resources I could go to for help was a strength for this course.
There were a plethora of opportunities for extra help, whether directly with Professor Steinacker or with a peer tutor.
Problem sets are wordy and unnecessarily complicated. Would recommend doing them in office hours because the way that they're written makes it hard to even interpret what the questions are saying.

I thought this was a remarkably well-taught course. Although the lectures provide exposure to new concepts and relevant examples, I learned the most by going to office hours and doing the problem sets by collaborating and trying things out with my peers. In that sense, the class is similar to a flipped-classroom in which most of the learning occurs outside of class while applying the concepts. I'm impressed by the sense of community that was created by the course, and become so close with such a large number of classmates in a lecture course. I appreciated that Professor Steinacker gave us time in some of the lectures to solve problems on our own, which made the class more interactive. I would love to see more of this individual or group problem-solving done more often, maybe one out of two lectures, to apply the concepts just learned. I also really appreciated the exam corrections for the midterms, which encourages students to lessen the focus on grades and more on learning. The main element that made me love the course was Steinacker's commitment to making us learn, by being present every day at office hours and hosting exam review and revision sessions, and taking the time to get to know and care for her students.
the lecture format was great and interesting. better support for the p sets would be nice.

A major strength of this course is Prof. Steinacker. She's absolutely wonderful, kind, patient, and genuinely cares about each of her students. She holds office hours every day and is always happy to help students. She is also a clear and engaging lecturer. A weakness of this course is that psets take a great deal of time every week, and could be reduced in length by a problem or two (though I understand why Prof. Steinacker makes them as long as she does; doing the psets is great prep for exams).

Strengths: many opportunities for students to get help
Weaknesses: long p-sets

AMAZING professor - great at teaching and cares more about her students than any other STEM professor I've ever had. Workload is super manageable - psets were often a refreshing break from the rest of the week, and office hours were always helpful for when you got stuck on the tricky ones. Tests were tricky but very reasonable.

Strengths: Great lecturer, both in terms of teaching ability and character; gives great foundation of physics; lots of support for problem sets; problem sets are challenging but fair, and they encourage growth of skills in physics; very hard to fail class if you try.

Weaknesses: Doesn't cover thermodynamics, relativity or a few other really interesting physics topics; not much that can be done about this since there's only so much time in a semester, but if you want to take this course, keep in mind that you won't see VERY advanced physics. TA's were sometimes a bit slow getting graded problem sets back, though I guess it's a pretty big class. Problem sets could be a bit harder.

The course was awesome. The psets each week were long and extremely hard, but there was so much support that you'd hardly notice. Prof. Steinacker made herself available for at least 12 office hours every week, which in my experience is unheard of for any professor. On top of that, there were TAs and peer tutors available at study halls and by email to help as well! And Prof. Stienacker is such a good lecturer - she sometimes went fast but she was thorough and posted class notes online so you could read through something again if you didn't understand it completely the first time. I was so scared to take physics but she made it doable, and now I'm actually excited for next semester!

I really enjoyed the applications to space and other ways in which Prof. Steinacker made information relevant in a real-world context. I felt as though I learned nearly everything in this class from doing the problem sets which I found to be both a strength and weakness of the class. The p-sets helped me get a good grasp on the material, but I often found that by attending lecture alone I would not have been equipped to solve the homework on my own (i instead had to go to peer tutor and office hours for many hours a week). As a humanities major taking this course, I understand the necessary rigor but wish that it could be more accessible to students outside of pre-med or STEM to take.

The course is overall strong--the organization and teaching were both strong.
The weakness is that since it is a large lecture class, Study Halls are usually flooding and it can be not the most efficient or productive for people trying to learn 1:1 from tutors. The peer tutor system can be set up better.
There are so many office hours, study hall hours, and peer tutors, willing to help. This is a very challenging class but there is help at nearly any time of the day.
Great lectures and good teaching pace, no complaints.
This strength is very well taught and the problem sets are very helpful.

This course is a very high work load, which is understandable but also very hard to manage at times. Professor Steinacker was very forgiving with exams and always willing to help, and I found it incredibly helpful that office hours, study hall, and peer tutor hours were all offered every day. This course is geared to help students succeed.

I think the strengths of the course are the support, the structure, and Professor Steinacker. I think that the class is well organized and for the most part reasonable. I think that the issue is that the homework assignments are either slightly too difficult or too long. I found that I was forced to try and finish them as fast as possible instead of learn the material.
The class is well taught but the PSETs are very challenging and time-consuming.

It is an excellent class. Very difficult, homework is almost impossible to do without going to office hours or tutoring. But the lectures are engaging and the homework is rewarding. Lots of opportunities to save your grade. A lot of work, but very worthwhile.
I wish the review sessions had been more helpful. I only attended one or two before I decided that they were not beneficial. They were just not as structured as I would have liked.

The strength of this course is its professor, Professor Steinacker. She is probably the most dedicated professor I have studied with. It's amazing how the professor's attitude can totally transform students' opinion about the material in the course. This course could be improved by making the wording on problem sets and exams clearer and less ambiguous/confusing. Other than that, PHYS 180 is excellent.
I really like the structures of the lectures, though I think the problem sets can be unnecessarily algebraic and don't always get at the meat of the concepts we're covering.

The strengths include that there are many opportunities to seek help through office hours and study halls, that detailed, helpful class notes posted for each lecture, that Professor Steinecker holds review sessions and sometimes exam feedback sessions, and that corrections are allowed on the midterm exams. The weaknesses include that the course is so time-consuming that it becomes difficult to focus on other courses and that the exams are often extremely difficult, resulting in such a low class average that everyone totally relies on the corrections. Further, the lectures often feel quite disorganized. It is difficult to read what is written on the board and follow what is happening. Most students express frustration over spending endless hours, several evenings each week, at office hours and/or study hall, completing the problems sets only after being walked through them by Professor Steinecker, teaching fellows, or peer tutors, but still feeling as if they don't understand the material or as if they would be able to work through the problems on their own.

The professor is fantastic and discusses each topic throughout, while giving numerous examples. She even provides different ways to solve each problem, so students would be able to chose the way they prefer for future related questions. The office hours for the course were immensely helpful, however sometimes I feel that there could be more help, since some sessions could get rather busy.
Strengths are it is well taught by a passionate professor. Weaknesses, office hours could maybe use one or two more TA's
Super hard. Professor is very engaging though.
I do not believe there was any weakness in the course. The main strength was Prof. Steinackers ability to break down concepts into extremely simple to understand ideas.
Problem sets are too long and hard. I hate that it is impossible to complete a single pset without going to office hours for help.

Adrianne is definitely the big plus of this course. Even though there are hundreds of students enrolled in her class, she takes the time to talk to you personally. She gives the lecture an amazing energy and her enthusiasm spreads to her students. 
Weaknesses are the way office hours can feel a but daunting. There is nowhere to sit and it is ovuercrowded, which is never good since you have to focus on the actual problem set. Another minus, is that the psets are long.  But this pays off in the end.
Really hard but the teacher is very passionate and really wants everyone to learn and not just worry about grades which is really refreshing
Course has great office hours TAs and times. No real weaknesses.

Steinacker is a wonderful professor! Her dedication to teaching is readily apparent every moment of class. Her enthusiasm for physics is outright contagious. She is the best part of the class.

My biggest complaint with the class was the psets. Overall, I found them largely distracting from the real material of the course. I was often frustrated by solving the physics of the given problems quickly, only to be bogged down by excessive math for the next few hours. I really didn't feel like completing the psets helped me learn the material better. Furthermore, as someone who did all of the psets outside of study hall and office hours, I wish that the psets contained less tricks that could only be given by peer tutors.
Hard psets but plenty of help available for students if seeked out through office hours and study sessions. Some concepts covered in class were a bit fast but overall everything was made clear.

Prof. Steinacker is a great professor so that was a strength of the course: an engaging professor and a skilled professor. Another strength was the accessibility to office hours and study halls; peer tutors and teaching assistants were always available as much as they could to help students, which is really great. There was also a review of topics weekly from one of the teaching assistants which I thought was helpful. Test corrections are also a huge plus. 

Not a weakness but something that is just a part of the course - it goes quickly which makes it demanding and sometimes hard to keep up with, but you have to keep up. P-Sets take a long time, multiple office hour sessions, and teamwork, and it's a lot of work for one class.

Strength: Exams are tough but fair. Numerous study halls and office hours offered weekly which really helps manage the course load.
Weaknesses: Some of the psets were almost too time- consuming but luckily these were compensated with extra time to turn them in.

Strength: I feel like I mastered the intended topics due to the difficulty of the problem sets. 
Weaknesses: hard problem sets but helpful in the end.
Problem sets were very difficult but a great study aid

The strengths of the class include the abundance of help available (office hours are held almost every day) and the generous grading. If you do the work and show up to office hours, it's not too hard to get a good grade. The psets, however, can be almost impossible to complete without going to office hours, so the class is extremely time intensive.
The psets are hard (impossible to do without help) but you end up learning a lot.

The course is difficult, so you need to go to office hours or study hall pretty often. On the other hand, you end up learning a lot, and the lectures are interesting. The problem sets are difficult but fair.
Dr. Steinacker is a wonderful instructor, and the support system of TFs, peer tutors, and her office hours were fantastic.
Very well taught. HW is exhaustive

The course's office hours were a blessing. A major strength. There were also peer tutor hours and study halls hosted by a peer tutor one could attend that were also incredibly helpful. As for course wide weakness, I do not believe there were many. Another great strength is being able to do revisions on the exams. That is an incredible privilege.

Strengths: helps you understand how the universe works, funny and helpful professor
weaknesses: psets are impossible without copious help, exams are challenging despite much studying
I would recommend this class to anyone who is interested in physics.
If you're taking it you have to so who cares.
This course was rough when I was taking it but I know that there's not a better professor out there to teach this class/a physics class where we would have learned more.
Yes, good physics introduction.
It's a solid physics class.
Absolutely. Prof. Steinacker is one of the toughest you'll get, while also one of the most kind and endearing teachers I've ever had. You'll learn a lot.

Absolutely.  I had only taken one semester of algebra-based physics my freshman year of high school and I felt I was adequately prepared for this class.  It is the level of rigor that an introductory physics class should be and to take anything less would be cheating yourself.

Overall, I would. The class is interesting enough and Professor Steinacker is great and really helpful. Her office hours make the homework sets a lot more doable. However, this class is difficult and there is a lot of work. If you do not manage your time with the homework, be prepared for some late nights.

This course is a huge time drain--so it's unlikely you're going to take it unless you have to fulfill a requirement. (I did, however, have some friends who took this course to fulfill a science credit; I don't know if I would recommend doing the same). However, I would highly recommend taking this course with Steinacker, if she is still teaching it. Steinacker is an eloquent lecturer, with a very unique personality that I'm sure you'll grow to appreciate, as I did.
Only to be taken as a pre-req. The course workload is too high for a class you take "for fun," which I say having done this course primarily for fun.
Yes, I think that this class serves as a great opportunity to cover the material that is often learned in high school physics with much more rigor and depth.

Yes - always go to office hours or meet a peer tutor or check answers with people who have done one or the other. She sometimes throws in things that you have not covered in class and won't be able to serve without going to office hours.
Yes. If you have to take a physics intro class then this one is well taught and offers the kind of help you need to succeed especially if you have no prior exposure to Physics.
Only if you need it
Yes. It is definitely the most challenging course I have taken at Yale, but also the most rewarding and the professor is simply incredible.

I would recommend that everyone who is not that excited about physics to take 170. The reviews for that class have been much better than for 180, mostly because of the instructor, but I'll talk about that in the instructor section.

Yes, absolutely. This course builds such a strong physics foundation that I think every student should have. It is not an easy course, but it is a fun one if you find the right people to study with and take the course with.
I defintely would recommend this course
Yeah! I have a friend who is a humanities major and she loves taking this class more than I did.

Only if you have HOURS to sacrifice every week. This has been more work than any other class I've taken (I'm a junior), including classes in my major. It definitely made all my other classes less enjoyable because I simply didn't have the time I needed to work on those in addition to physics. I essentially lived in HLH 17 working on problem sets every evening.
Not unless its for a requirement. Interesting course, but so much work
Yes, awesome class. Even for people who aren't STEM majors.
Only take this course if you absolutely need to. There is no other reason to take this course.

This course is actually amazing. The problem sets are daunting, but Professor Steinacker is THE BEST. She is extremely patient, and she pushes you to gain a deeper understanding of physics than you would otherwise. Would recommend over PHYS 170, which seemed to me was a more superficial look at physics than 180.
Yeah, professor's cool, but mainly just take it if you have to for pre-med or you're really interested in physics obviously.

Absolutely. If you have to choose between different kinds of physics, this one cannot be beat. You will learn the basic, fundamental principles that govern the universe, applicable to all scales and contexts. What's more beautiful than that?

Yes!!!! If you have to take introductory physics, take it with Steinacker!! The only people that will say to not take this course are the ones that probably skipped class or didn't go to office hours. If you take PHYS 180, make sure you have room in your schedule set aside for when you'll attend Adriane's OFFICE HOURS--not study hall. Study hall is fine, but if you have to choose between the two, go to office hours. In the first half of the course, I skipped class, went to study hall to work on psets I didn't understand, and then i FAILED the first midterm. The second half of the semester, I sat in the front row of every class and went to office hours as many times as I could, and then I scored above the class average on the second midterm. So, take PHYS 180 ONLY if you know you will devote time to truly getting help!! Also Adriane Steinacker is the best professor at Yale and there are test corrections (which literally saved my life)!
I would recommend this course but only if you have exposure to physics and are interested in physics/ willing to put a lot of time into the course.

I would recommend this to anyone interested in physics or how to solve problems in an analytical way. The course was very interesting and taught me how to solve problems by thinking about the concepts operate rather than plugging in numbers.

Absolutely. Professor Steinacker is truly passionate about her students, and she goes above-and-beyond to help each individual. She has a great deal of experience teaching this course, and therefore knows where students excel and struggle. Her exams are fair, though difficult, and address the major themes of the class.

Not really. I'm taking it as prereq, and most other people are too or for premed. Would not recommend if you're looking for a non-time-consuming SC credit for sure. Lecture also felt really slow and much simpler than the psets. Steinacker cares about her students, but the class itself isn't that enjoyable.

I would highly recommend this course to anyone seeking to take a physics class or getting a solid foundation in physics concept and engaging in rigorous thinking. Although I haven't taken or shopped other physics courses, I would highly recommend 180 as the introductory physics course to take!!
This is a great class! Lecture notes are posted to review again after class. Everything is very well organized and grading feedback is clea.
Yes! professor steinaker is an awesome lectiurer whos genuinely excited about the material.
Yes of course! You will get the help that is needed if you are struggling, and you will also learn so much.

I would recommend this course. It can definitely be a lot of work, and the weekly psets will take up ~8-10 hours a week, but Prof. Steinacker is incredible and you can definitely get through it with a good grade if you work hard. As a pre med, I thought the course content wasn't personally what I was most interested in, but the course was engaging nonetheless and I loved the problem-solving aspect of this class. It's pretty impossible to not like physics the way Steinacker teaches it.
Yes, only if with this instructor.

Yes, take it if you like physics or if you need to. Very manageable, taught MUCH better than 170, problem sets are not bad at all, GO TO OFFICE HOURS, if only to get to know Adriane - she's incredible!
I would recommend this course since the material is quite fascinating and its difficulty has enabled me to become a more efficient and adept student.

Absolutely! If you're pre-med like me, then you have to take a physics course. If, also like me, you don't feel comfortable going up to physics 200 or 260 and you're mainly choosing between 170 and 180, consider what you want out of a physics course. If you want a solid foundation in physics that appeals to all fields (medicine, engineering, physics, etc.), take 180, both because it covers the fundamentals of physics and because Professor Steinacker really knows how to teach. If you're comfortable with physics or just don't really care about having a solid foundation (not advisable), and really prefer seeing examples of physics in medical contexts, consider 170. Again, if you sincerely want to learn about and appreciate physics for what it is, 180 is probably better, but if you're just trying to complete the pre-med physics requirement, do 170. From what I've heard, that class is taught pretty well too, and it does provide some interesting biological examples of physics.

Absolutely! There's so much support from Prof. Steinacker and the TAs and peer tutors to make sure that everyone's succeeding. And Prof. Stienacker teaches the material in such a thorough manner and the different topics in such a naturally progressive way that it became easy to pick up with the right work. Just make sure you're doing the psets - the exam questions are very much structured like them (in terms of integrating different concepts, etc.), and it helps to have done similar problems once before! And go! to! class! I skipped a couple lectures for sickness, and it took me hours to make them up on my own rather than have learned them in class. Of course Prof. Steinacker accounts for such things with her attendance policy, but all I'm saying is don't skip class just because you want to! It's a lot to make up!
I would highly recommend this course, as it was taught very well.

If you have an interest in physics and this class relates to your major, absolutely. The course was incredibly well-structured to cover as much material as comprehensively as possible. However, if your major does not relate in any way to physics, you will be spending way too much time on this class.

I would recommend (although most people take it as a requirement) if you are interested in physics and want a straightforward science class. That being said, learning is very emphasized and you cannot breeze through PSETs like you may do for other classes, as the professor actually wants you to learn. That has both upsides and downsides.

This was a challenge if you did not take a good physics class in high school. However, it was easy if you took three physics classes in high school. IT  really depends on how much you wanted to be challenged and also if you need it for your major.
Yes without a doubt.
I would recommend this course for students that are interested in fields related to physics or engineering.
I would recommend this course to another student. While it is very time consuming and a high workload, it is a very rewarding course.
Yes, it is very well structured and not too difficult.
Only if you have to take it
Yes! Prof. Steinacker is an angel!

Yes, challenges are good and what make you grow. It is not an easy class, especially if you're not mathematically inclined, but it is worth the time commitment and the effort. If you don't have a strong interest in STEM or physics, it may not be worth it though; it will take significant time and effort.
It's an introductory course. If you need to take physics, take this class. I would not recommend it otherwise.

Yes, despite the fact that it is time consuming and requires hard work. This class is fantastic simply because Adriane Steinacker has dedicated her career to making sure you learn and succeed in her class. She is a marvelous human being and you should take her class just because of that!
Yes, because Professor Steinacker is an excellent teacher with a deep love of physics that permeates throughout the course. Solid foundations in mechanics are established over the semester.
No, I would not. It has been the most frustrating class I've taken at Yale.

Physics is one of my favorite subjects; having only an algebra-based background in the subject, it was nice to be able to incorporate calculus, as I had previously taken two years of it in high school. This serves as a great companion course to Math 120.
I would recommend this course to students who are interested in learning Physics or need to take the course for their major
Only if you HAVE to take this class. This is the hardest class Ive taken so far. It is unnecessarily hard.
Yes, the course is really good, and we receive extensive support through office hours.
Only if you have to
If you have the time, and take this class seriously it will be one of the best courses you will take at Yale.
Not if you don't need to, requires a lot of time if its not for your major
The professor is absolutely amazing. Steinacker is dedicated to her job and she'll demonstrate that to you quickly. Very clear instructor.
Only if you have to.

This was a great class. I would recommend over physics 200 any day. If you are planning on taking this class with physiological systems, be aware that the tests for the two classes are always one right after the other.

PHYS 170 and 180 both have their pros and cons; I suppose that I would recommend this course to another student, but I am not a physics/engineering major, so this class was a bit of a struggle for me personally. I had to work hard for it, but if you need to take this class, then go for it,  it's not as terrible as you think, especially with test corrections. Prof. Steinacker is great and super kind and super funny and she's a good teacher so I would recommend you take this class for her if you need to. But if you're just looking to fulfill a QR credit, then you should take another course.
Definitely would recommend this course because likely you have to take it but the professor is amazing and really cares about her students.
Yes! I love the professors! I learned a lot about mechanics and I feel like Ive mastered the material well.
Yes, definitely

If you're on the fence about taking this class, I would not recommend it due to the heavy workload. If you're motivated to learn the material though, the class is taught well and help is available to ensure students' success.
Yes, but you have to put in the time and effort if you want to learn anything.
This course is great for understanding physics given that you already have a calculus background. I would definitely recommend it.
I would, but I noticed a lot of students found it very difficult, whereas many others got over 100% on the midterms and worried minimally about the class.

Lectures were well organized and engaging, and it is clear that prof. Steinacker is passionate about teaching, and I always felt supported. I will say that I have never spent as much time on a pset as I did weekly with this class, and sometimes they felt punishingly long.  This is a good intro physics class, but be warned that a lot of time will have to be put into it.

Prof Steinacker is a wonderful instructor and she sets out the expectations for the course very clearly -- here is the thing though: The course is incredibly fast paced and very math heavy. Personally, my math background is very weak and i found it basically impossible to keep up with the prof in lecture. Even if you go to office hours/study hall every day, it can be hard to shake a feeling that you are the only one struggling to comprehend the material conceptually/ that you are kinda stupid when seeking help from T.A.'s or the prof. 

I think I may have had more success in the course if the homework problems were more structures such that a problem was divided into steps that would eventually lead you to an answer. I felt that a lot of time was wasted on homework problems trying to decipher what the question was asking and not knowing where to start. Problems like this showing up on the exam is far, but having all problems be so unstructured in the homework truly made the psets unnecessarily painful. 

As nice of an instructor as Adriane is... I'd recommend that my fellow math noobs and/or people who did not take AP Physics in high school take 170 instead, I hear those kids don't suffer as much.
Absolutely. Steinacker is an excellent instructor and the course teaches you a lot
I would only recommend it if it is a requirement.

If you are required to take physics, take this course. Prof. Steinacker does an amazing job with difficult subject matter. I took it for fun and do not recommend. Psets with copious, tedious algebra..
